newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Security tightened after Bangladesh shooting.
newsitem.headline: Security tightened after Bangladesh shooting.

text.p: Security reinforcements were sent in on Saturday to prevent further violence in an area north of Dhaka where a day earlier police had opened fire on villagers, killing seven, police said.

The situation in Sadhapur village remained tense on Saturday as police were confronted by angry mourners demanding that the dead bodies of those killed in the clash over a land dispute be handed over, local officials said.
Police and villagers said more than 100 people were hurt in the shooting.
The officials said the auxiliary police, known as Ansars, were called in on Friday to evict people occupying an unoccupied piece of land in the village.

"The unlawful occupiers started a battle with Ansars and at one stage, reinforced by villagers, attacked them with lethal weapons," one police officer at the nearby town of Savar, 40 km (25 miles) from Dhaka, told reporters.
"The Ansars opened fire in self-defence. Seven people were killed and over 100 injured in clashes," he said.

"Thousands of mourners, including friends and relatives of the victims, are pouring into the site, and demanding that the bodies of the seven be returned to them," a Bangladeshi newspaper reporter told Reuters in Dhaka.
"But they are told the bodies are in a morgue in Dhaka and cannot be handed back immediately. This would not pacify the villagers."
Police at the Savar station said reinforcements had been sent to the area from Savar and other nearby stations.
"We have occupied the land in Sadhapur village legally for generations but suddenly some people from outside are saying it's their land. We can't accept that," said 70-year-old Mohammad Jainal.
Police said they had heard the 100-acre (40-hectare) vacant area belonged to the Partex Group of Industries but the villagers had refused to leave.
"Suddenly everything slipped out of control and led to a bloodbath," one Savar police officer said on Saturday.
